content.title: Aberrant Right Subclavian Artery (Arteria Lusoria)
content.definition: Congenital vascular anomaly in which the right subclavian artery arises as the last branch of the aortic arch (instead of from the brachiocephalic trunk), coursing posterior to the esophagus. Most common aortic arch anomaly (0.5-2% of population), usually asymptomatic.

key_concepts.description: Results from persistence of the right dorsal aorta and involution of the right fourth aortic arch; normal development creates brachiocephalic trunk
Right subclavian arises from descending aorta as fourth and last arch branch; crosses midline posterior to esophagus (80%), between esophagus and trachea (15%), or anterior to trachea (5%)
Aneurysmal dilation at the origin of the aberrant vessel; represents remnant of right dorsal aorta; risk of rupture, compression, or dissection; may require surgical repair
Usually asymptomatic (80-95%); when symptomatic: dysphagia lusoria (difficulty swallowing from esophageal compression), dyspnea, chest pain, right arm ischemia (rare)
Dysphagia from esophageal compression by aberrant vessel; more common in elderly (atherosclerosis increases rigidity); classic association with this anomaly
Commonly associated with other congenital anomalies: Down syndrome (25%), congenital heart disease, right-sided aortic arch, Kommerell diverticulum
Barium swallow shows posterior esophageal indentation; CTA/MRA defines anatomy; often incidental finding on cross-sectional imaging
Symptomatic dysphagia lusoria; Kommerell diverticulum >3cm; associated aneurysm; asymptomatic patients typically observed
Subclavian artery transposition to right carotid; carotid-subclavian bypass with origin ligation; resection of Kommerell diverticulum (may require thoracotomy or hybrid approach)
Relevant for TEVAR planning - aberrant origin may require coverage; need to maintain right arm perfusion; may need debranching or chimney techniques

signs: May have BP differential if stenotic

learning_objectives: Define aberrant right subclavian artery and its embryology
Recognize dysphagia lusoria as classic presentation
Understand the significance of Kommerell diverticulum
Know treatment is usually only for symptomatic patients
clinical_pearls: Dysphagia lusoria = difficulty swallowing from esophageal compression
Kommerell diverticulum = aneurysm at origin - may need repair if >3cm
Usually incidental finding - observe if asymptomatic
Relevant for TEVAR planning - may cover the origin
common_mistakes: Attributing unrelated dysphagia to vessel (confirm by imaging/manometry)
